item.title: Function Pointers
item.dc:creator: @sh_ft sh!ft
item.description:
@sh_ft wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:9, topic:163257”][quote author=_cake link=topic=221890.msg1920094#msg1920094 date=1197153671]
moparisthebest, did your 80 year old college professor tell you this as he read binary?
[/quote]

That doesn’t make sense…[/quote]
It kind of does, he just didn’t outline his adjectives.

moparisthebest, did your 80 year old college professor tell you this as he read binary?

The italics are pointless extra information, I assume that were added for comedic effect. (In which case, he failed.)

The bold is the gist of the question.

item.title: Function Pointers
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Function Pointers are great, when used with reserve. Like most ‘features’ in a language, they can be used to make really nasty code when an interface or class would be much better (at least in OO languages, non-oo languages are forced to use function pointers).

Read full topic

item.title: Function Pointers
item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

Well, a Function Pointer is exactly what it sounds like, a pointer to a function, you declare a Function Pointer like so:

return_value (*name)(args)

example:

Let’s say we wanted to make a Function Pointer to a function we made called “println”:

void println(string s)
{
    cout << s << endl;
}

Ok, the function works, we all know this, so let’s make a Function Pointer to it:

int main(int argc, char** argv)
{
    void (*newPrintln)(string);
    newPrintln = &println; // the & isn't necessary, at least it didn't affect me any.
    newPrintln("Hello, World!");
    return 0;
}

As you can see, newPrintln(string) is just like calling println(string).

For a really good Function Pointer tutorial (I’m not really good with explaining things) please, refer to:
Function Pointer tutorials

P.S. This doesn’t really show a general use for a function pointer, just shows how to make one, let your mind wander and you can think of your own ways to do it, I can say 1 thing, I used it once for a small simple calculator I made…

int (*calculate)(int,int);

calculate = &add;
calculate = &subtract;

etc etc.

Read full topic
